Like a few other big investment banks, UBS leases space to ambitious young hedge fund traders as a temporary home, complete with receptionists, espresso machines and consultants to help manage their information systems.  In return, the banks hope the hedge fund hotel guests may become big clients.  Some regulators, however, are growing concerned about the relationship between the banks and their hedge fund hotel guests, looking at whether the banks might be using the real estate relationship as a way to entice hedge funds to do business with them, possibly at the expense of their investors.  William F. Galvin, the Massachusetts secretary of state, has subpoenaed UBS and is examining other banks with hedge fund hotels in Boston to determine how they are charging for their services. He is looking at whether hedge funds are paying higher than normal trading fees to banks to compensate them for the office space and failing to disclose this expense to investors.  ''It's a conflict of interest issue,'' Mr. Galvin said.  UBS, which declined to comment, is the leader in this business, with 400,000 square feet of hedge fund hotels in a number of cities. Bear Stearns is also active, with space for rent in New York, Boston, San Francisco and Los Angeles.  While the state investigation is in a preliminary stage and may not lead to any specific charges, at its heart is a thorny issue that has dogged regulators for decades. Money managers, including mutual funds and hedge funds, often pay Wall Street with ''soft dollars'' -- inflated commissions that include the cost of trading (typically 1 to 2 cents a share) plus an additional few cents a share that can be directed to pay for research and other services.  Soft dollars are controversial because clients pay for the higher commissions, while the services often benefit the manager the most. Higher commissions result in greater expenses for the fund and potentially lower returns for investors.  In the late 1990s, the Securities and Exchange Commission cracked down on the use of soft dollars by mutual funds, concerned that investors were being duped into paying for services enjoyed by the manager.  Massachusetts is now investigating whether hedge funds are improperly using soft dollars to pay for space in these hotels and failing to disclose to investors that they are covering a major expense.  ''It's the same soft dollar question,'' Mr. Galvin said in an interview. ''What kind of quid pro quo might be in the placement of an order? What's the relationship between the entities?''  As hedge funds have exploded, so, too, have the fortunes of Wall Street, which earns billions of dollars a year in fees executing trades and lending money to hedge fund clients. Hedge funds typically trade more than other Wall Street clients and they trade exotic, high-margin products, like complex derivatives.  Because hedge funds have become such important customers, there are concerns that they may be receiving tips about pending mergers, for example, or other yet-to-be-disclosed news that could affect a stock price. Trading ahead of public disclosure would give a fund an advantage; while it generally would be illegal, it is often hard for regulators to detect or prove.  Trading and the soft dollars used to pay for it are only one part of the business Wall Street does with hedge funds. The main business of servicing hedge funds is called prime brokerage. It includes financing trades; finding and lending stock to allow hedge funds to short stocks (betting that their price will fall); structuring derivatives; and executing swaps. It can also include hedge fund hotels -- securing real estate, receptionists and information technology and even managing, say, the risk of trading currencies in Asia.  The global prime brokerage business generates $8 billion to $10 billion a year, according to an estimate by the Vodia Group, a consulting firm for the financial services industry. The business is highly profitable, with a return on equity -- a measure of how efficiently the bank reinvests its capital -- of a healthy 15 to 20 percent. In 2006, Goldman Sachs made $2 billion directly servicing hedge funds, 22 percent more than the previous year.  Prime brokerage is only the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the fees that hedge funds generate for Wall Street firms: billions of additional dollars come from trading for these funds. Credit Suisse estimates that investment banks made $25 billion in revenue from hedge funds in 2004, $19 billion of which came from sales and trading and the rest from prime brokerage.  Hedge funds now control half the volume traded on the New York and London Stock Exchanges, according to Credit Suisse.  In markets like convertible arbitrage, hedge funds control 70 percent of the trading. (In convertible arbitrage, an investor buys a bond that can be converted into stock and then sells that stock short, betting that its price will fall because of the sale of convertible bonds.)  ''Hedge funds generate about 30 to 35 percent of the equity commission volume of the major Wall Street firms,'' said Brad Hintz, a securities analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a respected Wall Street research firm that manages money for wealthy individuals and institutions. But that is only part of the equation.  ''Because a hedge fund has broad investment guidelines -- it is not constrained like a mutual fund to invest in certain stocks or certain sectors -- it allows the hedge fund to really go after some of the more financially attractive products the Street offers,'' Mr. Hintz said.  In the United States, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Bear Stearns lead the pack in prime brokerage, collectively controlling about 75 percent of the market, according to Sanford C. Bernstein, a unit of AllianceBernstein.  But neither Goldman nor Morgan Stanley run significant hedge fund hotel operations. (Goldman inherited a small business from Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, which it bought in 2000.)  Bear Stearns' hedge fund hotel clients tend to be small. Bear is unusual because it accepts only ''hard dollar'' arrangements, rather then venturing into the murky area of soft dollars.  Bank of America exited the hedge fund hotel business 18 months ago because of a lack of demand.  Lehman Brothers and Credit Suisse have been building their prime brokerage businesses. Lehman has space that it leases to a select group of clients, but it is not a major player in hotel space. Credit Suisse prefers to cater to a small number of institutional-quality hedge funds that are expanding into high-margin products like structured derivatives and reinsurance.  Jefferies, a bank that caters to midmarket clients, recruited a significant part of Bank of America's prime brokerage team to build its business. Glen Dailey, head of prime brokerage, said the hedge fund hotel business was too expensive to build at Bank of America.  ''It took a lot of resources, especially tech support,'' Mr. Dailey said. ''Clients would call because there wasn't coffee or hot water. In the end, we felt like the client service group was spending 80 percent of its time on the real estate.''  Correction:  January 3, 2007, Wednesday  Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an investigation into the possibility that banks are luring hedge funds as tenants in order to solicit their trading business misstated the nature of a request made by the Massachusetts secretary of state, William F. Galvin, to UBS, the Swiss bank. While Mr. Galvin has requested information from UBS, he has not issued a subpoena. UBS is cooperating with the inquiry.
content.title: Banks' Leases To Hedge Funds Are Questioned

content.text: The Highbridge Capital Management hedge fund will announce today that it has taken a major equity stake in the energy business of the Louis Dreyfus Group, the old-line commodities trading firm, in a deal worth about $1 billion.  Highbridge Capital, a $17 billion hedge fund headquartered in New York that is majority owned by JPMorgan Chase, said it invested in Louis Dreyfus to gain more access to energy delivery and trading markets on its own.  The venture with Louis Dreyfus reflects a trend among larger hedge funds to try to diversify their investment offerings in an attempt to gather more capital.  ''We saw this as a real opportunity that is uncorrelated to everything else we're doing,'' said Glenn Dubin, managing partner of Highbridge. He explained that he had considered trying to get Highbridge into the energy trading business more heavily on its own, but concluded, ''there was no way we could do this by ourselves.''  Commodities have proved tricky for some multi-strategy funds. Amaranth, the $9 billion multistrategy fund that failed, had roots in a traditional investment strategy that then expanded aggressively into energy trading. Its initial success caused investors to pour billions into the fund, but when one energy trader made a series of bets that soured, the fund lost $6 billion in a week.  Highbridge and Dreyfus will jointly manage the venture, which will be called Louis Dreyfus Highbridge Energy and maintain its headquarters in Wilton, Conn. Before the Highbridge investment, Louis Dreyfus Energy was one of the 10 largest natural gas marketers in the United States and had worldwide interests in both the physical delivery of petroleum and natural gas as well as financial interests in energy.  JPMorgan Chase bought its stake in Highbridge in 2004 to gain exposure to the fast-growing hedge fund sector. The deal proved to be well-timed, as pension funds and other institutions continued to pour billions in to hedge funds, including Highbridge.
content.title: Highbridge Hedge Fund Buys Stake In Louis Dreyfus Energy Business

content.text: Citigroup reported fourth-quarter results yesterday that were good. The only problem was that its competitors have done so much better.  Citigroup's operating profit for the quarter rose 3.2 percent, led by a solid trading performance, improvement in its consumer business and big gains from its alternative investment unit.  But last year was particularly rough for the bank. For all of 2006, earnings fell 12 percent, to $21.5 billion. Citigroup shares gained nearly 15 percent for the year, though not until a big year-end rally.  ''It is no fun to score in the last two minutes of the game,'' Citigroup's chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, said yesterday on a lengthy conference call with analysts and investors. ''It is better than not scoring, but it is nerve-racking.''  Mr. Prince is under pressure from investors to rein in expenses and begin to show results soon. He has set out a long-term strategy that calls for integrating the bank's sprawling businesses and placing a greater emphasis on international and internal growth. Compared with many of its competitors, it must make up significant ground.  ''We're engaged in a very extensive, very transparent, multiyear effort,'' Mr. Prince said, sounding somewhat exhausted. ''It's not easy. It's not fast, and it's certainly not glamorous.''  Citigroup's trading performance was fairly robust, but paled in comparison to the blowout fourth-quarters posted by some peers. Citigroup's $2.75 billion in fixed-income trading revenue was up 32 percent from last year and equity trading revenue of $900 million was up 17 percent from last year. JPMorgan Chase showed a 77 percent increase in the fourth quarter from its fixed income and almost doubled its equity trading revenue. Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs reported similarly large gains.  Citigroup's expenses, meanwhile, remain high. Yesterday, the company said operating expenses were up 23 percent in the fourth quarter, while revenue grew 15 percent.  And a big tax benefit is about to disappear. If all the one-time tax benefits that will be gone next year were taken away in the fourth quarter, profits from all of the bank's consumer businesses were down from the third quarter.  There are also signs that credit quality is worsening. Mr. Prince noted a ''slight weakness'' in auto loans and second mortgages in the United States. Internationally, there are signs of potentially greater deterioration. In Mexico, a sharp increase in bad loans led to bigger losses and caused Citigroup to set aside an additional $111 million pretax in loss reserves.  ''I would emphasize that we are planning on headwinds from credit in 2007,'' Mr. Prince said.  Over all for the fourth-quarter, Citigroup's net income fell 26 percent from the quarter a year earlier, when it recorded a huge one-time gain from the sale of its asset management unit to Legg Mason. The bank was also hurt in the fourth quarter by an after-tax charge of $415 million related to the recent announcement that it would significantly cut back its consumer finance operations in Japan.  Net income from continuing operations rose to $5.13 billion, or $1.03 a share, from $4.97 billion, or 98 cents a share in the quarter a year ago. Revenue rose 15 percent, to $23.8 billion.  Citigroup shares closed yesterday at 54.50, up 11 cents, but the stock has long lagged its peers.  Still, Mr. Prince said the company delivered on its financial targets last year -- a remark that some analysts said suggested less about the bank's performance and more about a low bar. He once again emphasized Robert A. Druskin's new role as chief operating officer and expense-control czar. And he has tweaked the strategy, cutting back some investment spending and ramping up the bank's engine for small acquisitions, a move that could pay off faster but may sacrifice longer-term returns.  But delivering results will take time.  ''It would be really terrific if Rome were built in a day,'' Citigroup's chief financial officer, Sallie L. Krawcheck, said.  There were some bright spots in yesterday's results. Citigroup's consumer business in the United States showed modest improvement, though credit quality has remained unusually high. And net interest margins, which make up roughly half of Citigroup's revenue, appear to be stabilizing after months of sharp declines.  That should improve the quality of earnings, a research analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, Howard K. Mason, said.  ''I am happy to see there is some relief in sight,'' Mr. Mason said. ''If earnings quality improves, nobody will talk about that the C.E.O. is a lawyer and the C.F.O. is an analyst.''  ''You just will have a different story'' that is focused on Citigroup's growth, he said.
content.title: Citigroup Reports Good Quarterly Results

content.text: THE flow of earnings reports will pick up this week, but the earnings themselves are expected to show a dip in growth from past quarters. Any impact on share prices may depend on investors' expectations about those expectations.  Standard & Poor's estimates that earnings for companies in its 500-stock index rose by 9 percent, year over year, in the fourth quarter. That would be a healthy gain, but also the worst one in nearly five years, said Sam Stovall, S.& P.'s chief investment strategist.  ''This would be the first quarter in 19 where we've had a single-digit advance,'' he said.  But it has not been 19 quarters, or even two, since analysts last forecast single-digit growth.  Earnings estimates started off low for just about every quarter during the four-year bull market and then nudged up continually as fresh numbers came in. S.& P.'s forecast is close to those of other research firms, Mr. Stovall noted, but investors may still be disappointed if results meet expectations and nothing more.  ''Earnings are not going to grow at double digits forever,'' he said. ''The real question is: Is Wall Street prepared for the first single-digit advance in 19 quarters?''  One of the first big-name companies to report is Alcoa, which Mr. Stovall likened to a corporate Iowa for its status as a periodic bellwether.  S.& P. projects 150 percent earnings growth for aluminum producers, of which Alcoa is the biggest, and a result in that neighborhood on Tuesday would augur well for fourth-quarter earnings generally, and for 2007 economic activity, he said.  No triple-digit, or even double-digit, gain is foreseen for smaller companies. After increasing earnings at an annual rate of 17 percent or more in each quarter of last year, the S.& P. 600 index of smaller companies is expected to show growth of just 5 percent for the last quarter.  The gap in earnings growth is just one reason that Mr. Stovall expects investors to find larger companies more appealing than smaller ones this year. Smaller companies' run of outperformance is looking long in the tooth after seven years, he said, and indications of softening economic conditions could steer investors toward the comparative safety that blue chips are thought to offer.  ''It's getting later in the stock market and economic cycle,'' he said. ''When sailing into an impending storm, sailors prefer a larger ship.''  DATA WATCH -- The highlight of a thin post-holiday economic calendar may be the report on Wednesday of the nation's trade balance for November.  A Bloomberg News poll of economists forecasts a widening deficit, to $60 billion from $58.9 billion in October.  Retail sales for December, to be reported on Friday, are expected to rise by 0.6 percent after a 1.0 percent increase in November.  MARKET WEEK
content.title: Setting The Bar On Earnings

content.text: General Electric said yesterday that it would pay $4.8 billion in cash for Smiths Aerospace, the cockpit electronics arm of the London conglomerate Smiths Group. The two companies also said they would pool their technologies for detecting bombs, chemicals and other dangerous items into a joint venture, Smiths GE Detection.  The two deals give G.E. the ability to round out its aircraft engines business as well as increasing growth in its nascent security business. The deals give Smiths access to capital and research that its chief executive, Keith Butler-Wheelhouse, concedes the company needs badly.  In a statement, he said that ''increased capital requirements and the growing importance of supplier scale'' in the aerospace industry made it harder for Smiths business to grow.  The deal did not surprise G.E. analysts, many of whom noted that it was another sign that Jeffrey R. Immelt, G.E.'s chairman, would make good on his promise to get out of underperforming businesses and redeploy capital to fast-growing ones. Earlier this month G.E. said that it would acquire the oil and gas operations from Vetco International for $1.9 billion. G.E. also said it would seek a buyer for its lackluster plastics business.  ''Getting out of plastics, investing in oil and gas business last week and in aerospace and security this week, all of this is exactly in line with what they said they would do,'' said Daniel J. Rosenblatt, an analyst with Marble Harbor Investment Counsel, an investment advisory firm.  Under the terms of the deal, G.E. will pay about 1.8 times the Smiths unit's 2006 sales. Analysts say that considering the intense activity in the aerospace business, G.E. had little power to negotiate a lower price.  ''We are in a growing travel cycle, with more first-time travelers in China and Indonesia, with new airlines springing up, and with everyone buying more planes,'' said Virginie Maisonneuve, head of international equity investment at Schroders, a global asset management firm based in London. ''There aren't many companies out there that G.E. could buy, so you've got the law of supply and demand at work.''  Indeed, with this acquisition, G.E. goes into head-to-head competition with Honeywell International, a company that has long been a major player in electronic flight management systems. G.E. attempted to acquire Honeywell in 2001, but the deal was scuttled when European regulators deemed it to be anticompetitive.  In 2005, the European Commission acknowledged that some of the reasoning it used to reject the Honeywell deal might have been flawed. The commission has cleared 16 G.E. acquisitions since 2001, and few experts expect regulatory opposition to the Smiths deal.  Still, it is a combination that could make competitors sweat. GE Aviation, which had $13.2 billion in revenue in 2006, is a major supplier of jet engines and services for both commercial and military planes.  Smiths Aerospace, which has more than 11,000 employees and had $2.4 billion in revenue in 2006, makes the type of electronic flight management systems that GE Aviation has long needed to round out its portfolio. Smiths Aerospace controls are widely used by Boeing, a major G.E. customer, as well as by Airbus. The controls are used on both military and commercial airplanes.  G.E. is by far the more profitable of the two, and investors are expecting the Smiths unit to benefit quickly from an infusion of G.E. efficiency. ''G.E. has the resources to grow this business and make it competitive,'' said Timothy M. Ghriskey, chief investment officer at Solaris Asset Management.  Russell Wilkerson, a G.E. spokesman, amplified that thought. ''Their aerospace business has an 11 percent profit margin, ours has a 20 percent profit margin,'' he noted. ''We certainly can help expand theirs.''  Although G.E. has traditionally used stock to pay for at least part of its large acquisitions, the all-cash deal made sense, analysts said. In December, Mr. Immelt said that G.E. had ample cash on hand and was planning to spend at least $7 billion on industrial acquisitions this year. ''We have the cash available and this won't dilute equity,'' Mr. Wilkerson said.  Moreover, Smiths may well have made it a condition of the deal. Shares of the company, whose diversified portfolio includes medical devices, detection and a potpourri of industrial products, have performed poorly over the last year.  ''People are concerned about the lack of overlap between the businesses, but also about low margins in aerospace,'' said Mark Lovett, chief investment officer of RCM, the institutional equity arm of Allianz Global Investors.  Mr. Butler-Wheelhouse, the Smiths chief, has said he wants to return much of the money from the deal to shareholders. ''That would mean a stock buyback or special dividend, and it's hard to do either of those with a foreign company's stock,'' Mr. Ghriskey said.  Smith shareholders are clearly happy with the deal. The company's shares rose more than 11 percent on the London Stock Exchange. The New York Stock Exchange, where G.E. is listed, was closed yesterday.  G.E. shareholders are hoping the deal will eventually reflect well on their shares, which have had a hard time making it past the mid- to high-$30s for several years. ''This is a good deal, and it will ultimately come back to us, if not in a higher stock price than in dividends, buybacks or other ways,'' said Richard D. Steinberg, the president of Steinberg Global Asset Management, which counts G.E. shares as its largest holding.  In the long run, the formation of Smith GE Detection may have the bigger impact on the fortunes of both companies.  The joint venture will meld GE Security's homeland protection business, which had about $300 million in sales last year, with Smiths Detection, which had about $700 million in revenue in 2006. G.E. will own 46 percent of the company, and will have minority representation on its board.  Smiths GE Detection will be based in London. Mr. Butler-Wheelhouse will be its chairman, and Stephen Phipson, currently group managing director for Smiths Detection, will serve as its president.  Under the deal, G.E. cannot buy out Smiths for five years, unless Smiths -- which has on occasion been rumored to be a takeover target -- goes through a change of control.  G.E.'s agreement to be the minority partner in Smiths GE Detection is unusual, in that G.E. normally wants to apply its management efficiencies to any new company it invests in. Analysts say that Smiths, while eager to tap into G.E.'s global research operations, was adamant about not giving up control of the growing detection business.  ''Part of the reason they sold aerospace was to focus management's attention on growth areas like medical and detection,'' said Mr. Lovett, of RCM. ''So in detection they're sacrificing some equity in return for access to the G.E. name and resources.''  Correction:  January 18, 2007, Thursday  An article in Business Day on Tuesday about General Electric's purchase of Smiths Group's aerospace business misstated G.E.'s percentage of ownership of Smiths GE Detection, a joint venture between the companies. G.E. will own 36 percent, not 46 percent.
content.title: G.E. Buying A British Aerospace Company

content.text: In a move that has been expected for months, General Electric has begun shopping its plastics business to private equity funds, a person with knowledge of the details said yesterday.  The person said that Goldman Sachs, the investment bank that G.E. had retained to find buyers, had approached at least four equity groups, including Apollo Management, Bain Capital, the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. A deal could potentially be worth $10 billion.  Rising costs for chemical feedstocks like benzene, and increased competition that is holding down prices, have squeezed profits at the plastics division. This squeeze has tightened at a time when Jeffrey R. Immelt, the G.E. chairman since 2001, has promised shareholders that profit would grow at two or three times the nation's overall rate of economic growth.  G.E. announced in October that overall profit rose 10 percent in the third quarter over a year earlier.  Results would have been even better but for weak performance at the plastics unit, whose profit fell 23 percent to $152 million. Plastics account for about 8 percent of G.E.'s revenue and about 5 percent of profit.  With the auction still in its initial stages, potential bidders have been required to sign confidentiality forms and to agree not to speak with rival firms about forming consortiums without permission from G.E., people involved in the process said. The practice is increasingly becoming standard in an effort by sellers to keep auctions competitive.  G.E. is likely to allow certain firms to pair up later in the process, once it has established which firms are most interested in the asset.  For months, Mr. Immelt had declined to comment on growing speculation that he would sell the plastics division. But in the conference call to announce the quarterly results, he gave the first hint of what strategy he would pursue. While being careful to neither suggest a sale nor rule one out, Mr. Immelt emphasized that G.E. would invest only in specialized, higher-margin plastics, not the commodity plastics in its portfolio.  Making a sale at a good price may be challenging.  A year ago Apollo bought most of the plastics business of Tyco International for $975 million, acquiring 43 of Tyco's 51 plastics factories.  Apollo, which is controlled by Leon Black, bought Tyco factories in five countries that make trash bags, duct tape, plastic sheeting and similar products. Tyco held on to the A&E Products Group, the world's largest maker of plastic clothes hangers.  Tyco had tried to sell its plastics business in 2002, when it was still mired in the scandal that led to a prison term for its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski. Between the initial failed sale and the deal with Apollo, Tyco closed 30 plastics plants.  G.E. to Buy Vetco Gray  By The Associated Press  Citing strong global demand for energy, General Electric said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the oil services company Vetco Gray for $1.9 billion from a group of private equity funds.  Vetco Gray provides drilling, completion and production equipment for oil and gas fields. Its owners include Candover Partners, the 3i Group and JPMorgan Partners.  The business, which generated an estimated $1.6 billion of sales in 2006, has 5,000 employees, with operations in Houston, Britain, Norway and Singapore. G.E.'s current oil and gas business had about $3.6 billion in revenue in 2005, company officials said.
content.title: G.E. Is Said to Be Seeking A Buyer for Its Plastics Unit

content.text: MUTUAL funds made money across the board in the last quarter of 2006, in small- and large-cap stocks, and in growth and value shares. Some top-performing fund managers recently talked about some of their stocks and offered their thoughts about the year ahead.  Small Stocks, Big Gains  Small stocks led to big returns for the $78 million Pacific Advisors Small Cap fund, up 15.6 percent in the fourth quarter. The market capitalization for the 35 or so stocks in the portfolio averages $500 million.  The manager, George A. Henning, 59, says he looks for ''companies that are market leaders in their business, undervalued and have a good catalyst for future growth.'' Because he aims to hold stocks three to five years, he says, he buys what he calls ''less speculative stocks.''  He attributed the fund's fourth-quarter performance to a good overall economy. ''As the economy continues to move along, our stocks continue to perform well,'' he said. The fund carries a 5.75 percent front-end load, or sales charge.  One of its stars was ElkCorp, a company based in Dallas that Mr. Henning called the ''premier roofing company in the country.'' It became a takeover candidate, he said, when its share price fell because of slow sales during the light hurricane season last year. ElkCorp, which had agreed to be acquired for $38 a share by the Carlyle Group, is now weighing a bid from the Building Materials Corporation of America at $40 a share. ElkCorp rose 51.6 percent in the quarter.  Another winner was Terra Industries, an agricultural and industrial chemical company in Sioux City, Iowa. Sales in its ammonium nitrate fertilizer business have strengthened, Mr. Henning said, as prices of imported European ammonium nitrate have risen. The surge in domestic ethanol production has also contributed, he said, because ammonium nitrate is used in growing corn. The shares rose 55.4 percent.  The fund also made money in Toreador Resources, an oil and gas exploration and production company in Dallas. Its stock price dropped in the early fall on uncertainty about production levels in offshore wells, he said, but bounced back later in the year when it released positive reports about its preliminary findings. Its shares rose 43.9 percent.  Looking ahead, he says he is positive about stocks of all sizes. While share prices may initially drop after a strong year-end gain, he said, ''good growth may come in the second half of 2007 because many companies have good balance sheets.''  Finding Megatrends  Fast-growing companies drove the returns of the $160 million Eaton Vance Growth fund, up 14.3 percent in the quarter. The manager, Arieh Coll, 43, calls it a ''growth at a reasonable price'' portfolio. He seeks companies with annual earnings growth rates of 25 percent or more, or companies he sees as poised for rapid growth. The fund has a 5.75 percent front-end load.  To pick the fund's 85 stocks, Mr. Coll aims to identify megatrends in the economy, then looks for industries and companies that might benefit from them. In the fourth quarter, these were two commodity trends: rising prices for uranium, used in nuclear power plants, and for gold.  One of the fund's better performers was SXR Uranium One, a South African company whose shares trade on the Toronto and Johannesburg exchanges. SXR, a uranium and gold exploration and development company, owns properties in Canada, Australia and South Africa. He said the company should begin production in its Australian and South African mines next year.  ''SXR is constructing two mines that are scheduled to open in 2007,'' he said. ''Production costs are $15 a pound, so its earnings should start to rise rapidly.'' Uranium prices doubled, to $72 a pound, last year.  The company's shares rose 92.1 percent in the quarter.  The fund also profited from Gammon Lake Resources, a Canadian gold exploration and mining company that works primarily in Mexico. The shares, traded on the American Stock Exchange, rose 42.5 percent.  ''Ocampo, the company's biggest Mexican mine, increased its production in the fourth quarter, a signal that everything's O.K. at that mine,'' Mr. Coll said.  Another winner was Celgene, the biotechnology company in Summit, N.J. Celgene, which produces cancer drugs, recently began marketing Revlimid, used for patients with multiple myeloma. ''Sales are rising faster than expected,'' Mr. Coll said. ''Doctors are adopting the drug quickly because clinical data has proved its efficacy.'' Celgene shares rose 32.9 percent in the quarter.  This year, Mr. Coll expects interest rates to decline, which should be good for the stock market, but he anticipates slower economic growth.  A Boost From Commodities  Large value stocks propelled the $600 million John Hancock Large Cap Equity fund, which returned 10.5 percent in the quarter. The lead manager, Timothy Keefe, 44, says he picks the fund's approximately 50 stocks ''using a very disciplined approach to identify mispriced companies.'' The market capitalization averages $13 billion to $14 billion. The fund has a 5 percent front-end load.  Mr. Keefe says the fund profited in the fourth quarter from several commodities stocks. ''Some of the investments I made earlier in the year paid off in less than a year, which is unusual,'' he said.  One was Silver Standard Resources, a Canadian silver exploration and development company. Its shares, traded on Nasdaq, rose 39.5 percent. The company is a ''pure asset play,'' Mr. Keefe said. ''It's transitioning from a company that holds silver assets to a silver producer,'' he said. ''This will result in an upgrade in how the shares are valued.''  The fund also made money in Agnico-Eagle Mines, a gold exploration and development company in Toronto. He began buying shares in 2003, when it ''had a lot of difficulties with its biggest, best mine.'' Because of these difficulties, he added, ''its outstanding gold reserves were being underrecognized by the market.'' Its shares returned 32.5 percent.  Another winner was Bunge, a worldwide agricultural products company now based in White Plains. Its share price recovered from a drop in the summer, when difficulties with its Brazilian soybean suppliers created uncertainty about its short-term earnings, Mr. Keefe said. He expects the company's profit to rise in 2007 in tandem with rising soybean prices. In the quarter, shares returned 25.4 percent.  He expects a volatile stock market in 2007, which he sees as providing valuable opportunities.  ''There are a lot of crosscurrents in the market with the U.S. dollar, interest rates and disagreements about how fast the economy is growing,'' he said.  MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT
content.title: Three Philosophies, Three Big Gains
